awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Building Women Leadership at  field stations and marine laboratories
awd_abstract_narration:
Field stations and marine labs (FSMLs) provide a network of facilities that enable observations and experimental research on a myriad of biological processes to monitor the effects of a shifting climate. Field-based institutions represent a unique resource in the nation's scientific infrastructure and present invaluable opportunities for the translation of scientific discovery into education, public engagement, resource management, and policy. FSMLs face unique challenges, including their remote locations, limited resources, group living conditions, and constrained communications. The extent to which these challenges pose barriers to ensuring diversity and equity in participation in field science is poorly understood. While participation of women in the biological sciences has been generally increasing, equity in leadership positions, salaries, and career advancement continues to lag behind expectations. The value of the nation's network of field stations is compromised in the absence of inclusive and equal participation in science by all members of the community.  The long-term vision for this project is to increase the number of women leaders at field-based institutions and create an inclusive culture in which women feel prepared, supported and empowered to lead. 
 
With this grant, funds are provided for planning activities to gather data about the needs of women leaders in order to fully define the status quo, to design an effective strategy for leadership training with experts in the field and who have experience with issues of equity and inclusivity, and to identify training workshop deliverables. Through a community survey and a facilitated planning meeting with a diversity of participants, this project will assess the current state of gender equity in leadership at FSMLs and identify areas of need and opportunities. These will be used to form a set of design requirements for a pilot leadership training program.  The project will work closely with the relevant societies such as the Organization of Biological Field Stations and the National Association of Marine Laboratories. A final deliverable will be a strategic plan for identifying barriers and potential solutions to increase and support women leadership at field stations and marine laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In an era filled with the overexploitation of natural resources, unstable food production, and rapid climate change, a strong and clear understanding of the natural world is more important than ever. Field stations and marine laboratories (FSMLs) are sentinels of Earth’s climate, environment, and biodiversity that provide scientists with the infrastructure to collect data in otherwise inaccessible areas of the globe. FSMLs offer a window into the increasingly unpredictable natural world that is challenged by progressively frequent natural disasters and extreme climates.

Field Stations and Marine Labs (FSMLs) provide vital insights into the increasingly unpredictable environmental conditions; however, FSMLs remain exclusive facilities that require economic, social, and networking capital to allow scientists and staff to live, work, and study in these isolated locations. While FSMLs provide invaluable access and opportunities for scientists to explore relatively pristine habitats, remoteness can be demanding and often require users to take extreme measures to adapt, survive, and thrive. Although there appears to be more women employed at field-based institutions than in the past, they may not have the same experiences or access to leadership and sponsorship activities/opportunities as their male counterparts. Moreover, their male counterparts may not be aware of the barriers they face or believe that gender equality in FSMLs has already been “fixed”. Our pilot survey and focus groups have highlighted the need for further exploration into women’s experiences through the use of focus groups and interviews. For women at FSMLs, their identity may be reduced to that of a nurturing caretaker of the land and visitors, and both as staff and visitors, they are expected to fit into traditional binary gender roles. Our results help to inform the creation of the Leadership Academy and Mentoring Network to better support and empower women to obtain leadership positions in FSMLs.

This planning grant has advanced the capacity for research and training opportunities by: 1) characterizing the current Field Station and Marine Lab (FSML) organizational culture; 2) identifying barriers that women face to obtaining leadership positions at FSMLs; 3) and developing pilot strategies, programs, and interventions for supporting women’s leadership roles at field laboratories, as well as developing best practices for policy, resource allocation, and field station design to better support and increase women’s leadership roles at FSMLs. Our findings suggest that although there are more women in field-based institutions, these new female recruits may not have the same experiences or access to leadership and sponsorship activities/opportunities as their male counterparts.

Key outcomes include exploratory survey data, a book submission (Women of the wild: Challenging gender disparities in field-based institutions), creation of a digital presence for supporting/promoting women in leadership within FSMLs and building stakeholder interest in the project. The Women Leaders at Field-Based Institutions project identifies the necessary changes that need to occur in the field-based institution culture to better promote women into leadership roles and diversify within field-based institutions. Increasing cross pollination and equitability in the pursuit of scientific knowledge and sharing of that knowledge across different career stages, disciplines and a broader scope of public accessibility (an edited volume). This project has benefited tremendously from the partnership across an interdisciplinary team of scholars who integrate the experiences of field scientists from distinctly distinct institutions with sociologists with expertise in communication practices and theories that carefully examine the conditions of conducting science outside of traditional laboratories and the built environment. These theories and qualitative research measures have been used to identify the barriers women face to leadership opportunities, as well as inform recommendations to eliminate these barriers and to empower an increasing number of women into leadership positions within field-based institutions. Continued partnership with social science disciplines will help to eliminate these barriers and develop stronger interdisciplinary ties for future research projects.
